ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to write a serious work of art historical scholarship.
I learned how to devise an argument for, conduct research and analysis, and write a 25-30 page thesis.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Excellent feedback and sense of community.

I found the workshop structure of the course worked best with my schedule, especially when supplemented with meetings from my advisor. This made it so we had all the necessary information and development of skills, but it did not feel like it was continually subtracting from time, which could be better spent elsewhere.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are an art history major, it is a requirement.
This is a required course to graduate, so yes, if you are an Art History major, you should take this course.

My recommendations/the stuff I learned: 

- I do not recommend writing a single-semester thesis in the fall (shockingly). I thought there wouldn't be much of a difference and did mine in the fall to get it out of the way/ enjoy my final semester, but I think I would've been more prepared/less stressed had I done it in the spring. 
- I do not recommend writing your thesis at the same time as 401 (also kind of shocking).  it's not that 401 is necessary to be able to write your thesis (in fact, I found it to be a rather poorly taught class), but I do think 40's final paper sets you up for the kind of thinking/analysis that will eventually come up in your thesis. From a practical standpoint, it's also just way too much writing for a single semester (~30 pages here + ~15 pages in 401 + however many more pages you have in your other classes, all during finals period. It's a nightmare). 
- I do not recommend taking it during a semester with 4.5 credits or more. Let this be the beefy part of your schedule.
- One page of clean(ish) writing took me at least three hours of brainpower (single spaced).
- Do not leave until the end bc it really isn't that kind of thing (coming from a person who has made everything that kind of thing at Yale :/ ) 
- Time and structure are the hardest part of the thesis, not the exercise itselfit's just more of the same writing we do in most classes here.
